author: Lucille Keen
title: Union takes money from rehab centre to boost 'fighting fund'
text:
It has been alleged the militant construction union took funds understood to be tagged for the drug and alcohol rehabilitation centre, Louie Douvis by Lucille Keen "Frustration and disgust" led to Master Builders Association executive director Brian Seidler to quit the construction industry's charitable drug and alcohol rehabilitation facility after discovering the union was siphoning more than half the money raised for its own use.
Mr Seidler said he resigned from the committee of management of the Construction Industry Drug and Alcohol Foundation in 2012 after almost 20 years when it became apparent the NSW division of the Construction, Forestry, Mining and Energy Union was taking money meant to be for Foundation House, a rehabilitation centre.
"We had no inkling that the money was not coming to Foundation House because we had no financial problems," Mr Seidler told the Royal Commission into Trade Union Governance and Corruption.
"We had – or I had, along with other committee of management members, had been struggling for probably nearly a year to find out where funds from industry had gone so that they would be able appropriately paid to the Foundation which was to help people in need.
"We were getting nowhere. I think it was more frustration and disgust, to be honest, that we found that monies that we believed were allocated to go to people who need assistance was not coming to those who needed it."
Foundation House, a rehabilitation facility in Sydney, has been operating since 2000 and is funded in partnership with the building industry through a union charity known as the Construction Industry Drug & Alcohol Foundation Treatment Centre.
The charity was funded with a clause in workplace agreements that requires companies to pay a mandatory levy, which started at $1 a week for each employee and is now up to $3 a week.
The clause dealing with the drug and alcohol levy was changed to include payment for safety work undertaken by the union.
 ​The allegations that the CFMEU used the clause within the agreements to raise up to $1 million for union activities was reported by The Australian Financial Review in 2012 .
Prior to this, high-profile committee members including Mr Seidler, prominent activist and widow of NSW judge Bob Bellear, Kaye ­Bellear and Bovis Lend Lease executive Colin Huntley resigned after discovering the money had been diverted to the CFMEU.
Mrs Bellear told the Commission on Monday the committee wasn't getting answers as to where the money was going.
"And I felt that because of my long involvement or my family's long involvement in the trade union movement, that I did not want to be involved in something that I thought was wrong," Mrs Bellear said.
In a letter Mrs Bellear wrote to Mr Huntley prior to resigning she requested her name and her late husband's name be removed as patrons of the organisation.
Devastated by misuse of funds "I am devastated and disgusted by the misuse of the donations to the Foundation," she said in the letter.
She wrote it was "appalling" that workers and employers believed that they were donating to the Foundation through EBAs when in actual fact the CFMEU was keeping at least leave half of the money.
​Counsel assisting the Commission Sarah McNaughton SC said it was "clear that issues of conflict of interest, transparency and accountability are important issues to explore in this context".
"In addition, the circumstances in which the money was obtained by the CFMEU give rise to additional issues including potential breaches of trust and obtaining money by deception," Ms McNaughton said.
CFMEU official Michael Knott, who was one the committee of management for the foundation, told the inquiry he first heard that money from the workplace agreements meant for the charity was going to other areas of the union from then CFMEU NSW secretary Andrew Ferguson.
"Foundation House simply received a donation from the levy regularly on a monthly basis," Mr Knott said.
In his witness statement, Mr Knott said described a $100,000 "donation" to Foundation House from construction company Theiss following a worker safety incident was a "fucking kickback".
Mr Knott said that he warned another CFMEU official, Steve Dickson, that the union should have nothing to do with it because it amounted to "corruption".
The hearing continues.
